awd_titl_txt: II-New:  Towards Green Data Centers:  A Testbed for Thermo-Computational Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration: This project develops a testbed for experimentation with energy saving in data centers via holistic management of both the computing and cooling subsystems. It instruments a large computing cluster at the University of Illinois that reproduces representative dynamics of energy consumption in data centers. Understanding heat and energy dynamics in large computing systems requires detailed sensing and control on both the computing and cooling side. The goal is to produce models and algorithms that significantly contribute to energy optimization research leading to reductions in carbon footprint and operating costs of contemporary computing clusters. The testbed developed in this project focuses primarily on understanding and improving software-controlled mechanisms for energy optimization in systems that exhibit non-trivial coupled thermal and computational dynamics, called thermo-computational systems, towards better energy management of data centers. When complete, it is likely to become the first and largest open testbed geared for enabling high quality research on large thermo-computational systems. The project is motivated by the increasing energy cost of data centers, which is estimated at more than $4.5 billion annually and is expected to grow at a rate of 12% in the absence of intervention. According to the EPA, most of this cost is avoidable. If successful, the project will therefore contribute significantly to both the economy and the environment by resulting in savings in both energy cost and carbon footprint.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a testbed for experimentation with energy savings in data centers via holistic management of both computing and cooling subsystems. The testbed enabled development and evaluation of multiple data center resource management policies that were shown to significantly reduce total energy consumption and improve sustainability of data services. The work is motivated by the alarming growth in world data and, correspondingly, the large growth in data center energy consumption and emissions, significantly outpacing other sectors. According to a recent report by the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), US data centers consumed an estimated 91 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity in 2013. It is to be compared to 61 billion kilowatt-hours in 2006 according to the Environmental Protection Agency. The NRDC report further predicts that total data center energy consumption will reach 140 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity by 2020, emitting nearly 150 million metric tons of carbon pollution per year. What's most troubling about this prediction is not so much the net amount (which constitutes about 2% of total US energy consumption by some accounts), but the trend. This trend is roughly equivalent to a doubling of energy use every decade. In contrast, according to the Energy Information Administration, US residential energy consumption has risen by only 10% in the last 30 years (or only 3% per decade), and is presently declining. Similarly, the emissions of the transportation sector have increased by only 8% in the last decade and are presently declining as well.

The alarming trend in data center energy consumption means that data centers will account for an increasing fraction of energy and emissions in the nation over time. The testbed built in the current project helps the research community replicate, for data centers, the success achieved in curbing energy consumption of the residential and transportation sectors. Indeed, in September 2014, the White House expanded its Better Buildings Challenge to data centers, setting a goal to make them at least 20% more energy-efficient by 2020. By exploiting the current testbed, researchers have already been able to demonsrate novel resource management algorithms that achieve this improvement in energy efficiency, without sacrificing capacity. Since the testbed enables extensive measurements (as well as control), it enables researchers to demonstrate (by performing measurements on an actual platform) that the savings are real in practice, and not merely a product of analysis and simulation. We hope that this added confidence, that stems from empirical verification, will inspire a faster path to adoption and hence contribute to meeting the White House's Better Building Challenge for data centers.

On a technical level, the testbed developed in this project features a cluster of machines instrumented to enable accurate measurements of dynamics of energy consumption and temperature variations in data centers. Understanding these dynamics requires measurements on both the computing side (to understand load distribution) and the cooling side (to understand thermal dynamics). The testbed is complete with sensors, such as temperature sensors and power meters, as well as actuators such as temperature and humidity control that allow researchers to manipulate, observe, and model interactions among attained temperature, consumed power, and performed computation in machine clusters of non-trivial scale.

Besides enabling extensive measurements, a unique advantage of this testbed lies in the broad set of controls that it makes available to researchers.
